docs.lead_paragraph: Eric Hinske had a bases-loaded triple and Dustin Pedroia hit a two-run double last night as host Boston’s bats came alive in a 7-3 victory against the Texas Rangers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Unlike Daisuke Matsuzaka, Hideki Okajima did not come with a nine-figure price tag or the international intrigue of baseball’s posting process. His signing was not broadcast live on two continents. Okajima came in under the news media radar.

docs.lead_paragraph: BASEBALL LESTER FREE OF LYMPHOMA -- Doctors treating Boston Red Sox pitcher Jon Lester have told him he is free of lymphoma, and he is planning to report to training camp on time. ''It was my expectation from the beginning to be at spring training at some point,'' Lester, a 22-year-old left-hander, said yesterday. ''Now that everything is looking good and ready to go, I'm ready to be there on the reporting day that pitchers and catchers need to be there.''
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox pitcher Jon Lester is free of lymphoma (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Curt Schilling is not the Curt Schilling of 2004, which is something he has repeatedly acknowledged. That means he is not the dominant pitcher who helped guide the Red Sox to an inspirational World Series title one year ago. He might never be that pitcher again. But whatever semblance of that dominance is still inside Schilling's right arm remains crucial to the Red Sox. The Red Sox have depended on Schilling as if he were the same pitcher from last year, even though they know that is not realistic. The desperate Red Sox had no other choice.
docs.snippet: Whatever semblance of that dominance that is still inside Curt Schilling's right arm remains crucial to the Red Sox....

headline.main: No Longer Dominant, Schilling Is Still an Ace

docs.lead_paragraph: Curt Schilling will not be throwing many pitches in the next two weeks. And do not expect him to throw any bouquets in Lou Piniella's direction, either. Schilling, the ace right-hander for the Boston Red Sox, will miss at least two weeks with a bruised bone in his surgically repaired right ankle, the team announced yesterday.

headline.main: Schilling Injures an Ankle, And Piniella's Feelings

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor: I had to smile when I read ''Close Doesn't Always Count in Winning Games.'' The Times writers just don't give up when it comes to puffing up the home team, do they?
docs.abstract: Claire Daniel letter contends that team unity helped Boston Red Sox win 2004 World Series (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The filmmakers Peter and Bobby Farrelly have been scrambling to rewrite dialogue and a final scene for the romantic comedy ''Fever Pitch,'' which is plotted around the love life of an obsessive Boston Red Sox fan (Jimmy Fallon) and his vain belief that his team will win a World Series. Whoops. ''When we made the movie, it was always, wink, wink, 'What if the year we make the movie is the year they win the World Series?''' said Elizabeth Gabler, the chief executive of Fox 2000, which is making the film for 20th Century Fox. The filmmakers shifted the story timeline to match the playoffs and inserted dialogue to account for Boston's World Series victory this week. They also shot a coda to the film, which has Mr. Fallon and his love interest, Drew Barrymore, above right, running onto the field at the real-life moment of the Red Sox historic triumph over St. Louis. ''It made for a magical fairy tale ending,'' Ms. Gabler said. SHARON WAXMAN
docs.abstract: Arts, Briefly column; filmmakers Peter and Bobby Farrelly, following World Series victory, scramble to rewrite dialogue and final scene for romantic comedy Fever Pitch, about love life of obsessive Boston Red Sox fan; photo (S)
